title: Rename SP to Waggle
description:
Rename the library from SP (Scalability Protocols) to Waggle, using the bee waggle dance as the central analogy. The waggle dance is how bees communicate task locations to other bees - a natural fit for a messaging/coordination protocol library.

## Analogy Mapping

| Technical Concept | Waggle Term | Usage |
|------------------|-------------|-------|
| The library | waggle | Package/module name |
| Publish/send | dance | Announcing where work is |
| Subscribe/receive | watch | Observing announcements |
| Message/payload | nectar | What gets carried |
| Node/endpoint | bee | Individual participant |
| Network/system | hive | The connected whole |
| Discovery | scout | Finding peers |
| Connection | flight path | Route between bees |
| Broker/relay | comb | Central coordination point |

## Scope

This epic covers updating all documentation to use waggle terminology consistently. No code changes needed as the project is in documentation phase.

## Tone

The waggle dance is nature's pub/sub protocol. Lean into this - it makes the library memorable and concepts intuitive. Keep explanations grounded but allow the whimsy of the analogy to make docs approachable.

title: Create Product Requirements Documents (PRDs)
description: All PRD documents created in doc/prd/: transport-abstraction.md, shared-infrastructure.md, io-workers.md, req-rep-protocol.md, socket-api.md, testing-strategy.md, additional-protocols.md, async-api.md

title: PRD: Transport Abstraction Layer Design
description:
**Requirements:**
- Design transport abstraction supporting Unix domain sockets and raw IP sockets
- Document interface that transport implementations must satisfy
- Define test suite for transport compatibility
- Specify performance requirements and benchmarks

**Design Decisions:**
- How the abstraction hides transport-specific details
- Interface for dial/listen/send/recv operations
- How message boundaries are preserved
- Backpressure and flow control mechanisms

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Transport interface is fully specified
- Test compatibility suite is defined
- Performance benchmarks are documented
- Design supports both Unix sockets and raw IP

title: PRD: REQ/REP Protocol Engine Design (Phase 1)
description: PRD document created at doc/prd/req-rep-protocol.md. Covers REQ and REP state machines, request ID correlation (32-bit MSB set), automatic resend with configurable timeout, backtrace header handling, and round-robin load balancing.

title: PRD: I/O Worker and Syscall Handling Design
description: PRD document created at doc/prd/io-workers.md. Covers RecvWorker (continuous read loop), SendWorker (channel-driven writes with drain), WorkerPair (unified lifecycle), backpressure via channel fullness, and error handling strategies.

title: PRD: Socket API and Blocking Interface Design
description: PRD document created at doc/prd/socket-api.md. Covers Socket factory pattern, blocking Send/Recv API, Dial/Listen connection management, Options pattern for configuration, Context support for cancellation, and clean lifecycle with graceful shutdown.

title: PRD: Testing Strategy and Quality Assurance
description: PRD document created at doc/prd/testing-strategy.md. Covers unit tests for all components, integration tests for end-to-end flows, benchmarks with performance targets, race detector validation, goroutine leak detection, and CI/CD integration.

title: PRD: Go-Native Async API Design (Phase 2)
description: PRD document created at doc/prd/async-api.md. Covers channel-based send/recv interface, context integration for cancellation/timeouts, select compatibility, sync/async mixed usage, pattern-specific channel semantics, and migration guide from sync API.

title: PRD: Shared Infrastructure Design
description: PRD document created at doc/prd/shared-infrastructure.md. Covers Message Buffer Pool (sync.Pool-based with stats), Peer Registry (RWMutex, dual-indexed by ID and address), Connection Registry (maps transports to sockets), and Message type with buffer lifecycle.

title: PRD: Additional Protocol Patterns Design (Phase 2)
description: PRD document created at doc/prd/additional-protocols.md. Covers PUB/SUB (topic filtering, fan-out), PIPELINE (round-robin load balancing), SURVEY (deadline-based response collection), BUS (many-to-many mesh), and PAIR (exclusive bidirectional channel).
